snippet: Two advocacy groups left for Turkey to meet with the officials, who may include President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
lead_paragraph: Two advocacy groups left for Turkey to meet with the officials, who may include President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
abstract: International delegation representing two leading press-freedom advocacy groups are scheduled to meet in Turkey with Turkish officials, possibly including Pres Recep Tayyip Erdogan, about harassment and persecution of foreign and domestic journalists whose reporting is deemed hostile or unfair by the government.

headline.main: Advocates for News Media to Meet Turkish Officials
headline.print_headline: Supporters of Free Press Visit Turkey

snippet: How would you like to take over as the United States ambassador to a close ally that your vice president just accused of effectively helping Al Qaeda and the Islamic State? Just ask John Bass, the career Foreign Service officer who will be...
abstract: How would you like to take over as the United States ambassador to a close ally that your vice president just accused of effectively helping Al Qaeda and the Islamic State? Just ask John Bass, the career Foreign Service officer who will be ceremonially sworn in Tuesday as the envoy to Turkey.

headline.main: A Diplomat With a Finger in His Collar

snippet: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey spoke on Wednesday at the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly.

snippet: Forty-nine hostages held by Islamic State militants were returned to Turkey on Saturday after what Turkey said was a covert operation led by its intelligence agency.
lead_paragraph: Forty-nine hostages held by Islamic State militants were returned to Turkey on Saturday after what Turkey said was a covert operation led by its intelligence agency.
abstract: Forty-nine hostages held for more than three months in Iraq by Islamic State militants are returned to Turkey after what Turkey says was a covert operation led by its intelligence agency; Turkey insists that no military actions were taken and no ransoms were paid.

headline.main: Turkey Obtains Release of Hostages Held in Iraq
headline.print_headline: Turkey Obtains Release of Hostages Held in Iraq

snippet: The New York Times and one of its Istanbul correspondents have been denounced with growing furor in reaction to an article and photograph about the recruitment of fighters in Turkey by the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times and one of its Istanbul correspondents have been denounced with growing furor in reaction to an article and photograph about the recruitment of fighters in Turkey by the Islamic State.
abstract: Turkish Pres Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his supporters have been denouncing The New York Times and Ceylan Yeginsu, one of the paper's correspondents, with growing furor, reacting to article about recruitment of fighters in Turkey by Islamic State militant group.

abstract: Obama administration begins work of trying to determine what roles members of its fledgling coalition of countries to fight Islamic State in Iraq and Syria will play; Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel meets with leaders in Turkey, country that administration has called indispensable to the fight.

lead_paragraph: Ahmet Davutoglu was elected leader of the governing Justice and Development Party, or A.K.P., on Wednesday, ahead of his expected appointment as prime minister on Thursday.
abstract: Ahmet Davutoglu is elected leader of the Turkish governing Justice and Development Party, ahead of his expected appointment as prime minister.

headline.main: Turkey: Likely Premier Is Party Leader
headline.print_headline: Turkey: Likely Premier Is Party Leader

snippet: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the former prime minister who has governed Turkey for more than a decade, is expected to continue to exercise power for at least another five years.
lead_paragraph: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the former prime minister who has governed Turkey for more than a decade, is expected to continue to exercise power for at least another five years.
abstract: Turkey's former Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan is sworn in as country's first directly elected president; he is expected to continue to exercise power for at least another five years.

headline.main: Erdogan Is Sworn In as President of Turkey
headline.print_headline: Turkey: Erdogan Sworn In as President

snippet: The continued presence of Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s appointees at the head of key ministries left little doubt that the president would retain strong influence over the government.
lead_paragraph: The continued presence of Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s appointees at the head of key ministries left little doubt that the president would retain strong influence over the government.
abstract: Ahmet Davutoglu,Turkey’s prime minister-designate, announces a new cabinet dominated by holdovers from his predecessor Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

headline.main: New Cabinet in Turkey Mirrors That of Last Premier
headline.print_headline: New Cabinet in Turkey Mirrors That of Last Premier

snippet: Turkey’s governing party nominated Ahmet Davutoglu to succeed President-elect Recep Tayyip Erdogan as prime minister and party chairman.
lead_paragraph: Turkey’s governing party nominated Ahmet Davutoglu to succeed President-elect Recep Tayyip Erdogan as prime minister and party chairman.
abstract: Turkish Foreign Minister Ahmet Davutoglu is chosen by the ruling Justice and Development Party to succeed President-elect Recep Tayyip Erdogan as prime minister and party chairman; his nomination will go to vote at party congress, where it is expected to go unchallenged.

headline.main: Foreign Minister Ahmet Davutoglu Nominated to Be Turkey’s Next Premier
headline.print_headline: Foreign Minister Nominated to Be Turkey’s Next Premier

byline.contributor: Ceylan Yeginsu reported from Ankara, and Sebnem Arsu from Istanbul.
byline.original: By CEYLAN YEGINSU and SEBNEM ARSU

snippet: Turkey is caught between conflicting interests: defeating Islamic militants across its border with Syria while not strengthening Kurdish separatists inside Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Turkey is caught between conflicting interests: defeating Islamic militants across its border with Syria while not strengthening Kurdish separatists inside Turkey.
abstract: Chaos on Turkey's border with Syria and Turkey's ambivalent reaction to fighting between Kurds and Islamic State group are reflection of nation's complex role in Syrian civil war; Turkey does not wish to enhance power of its own Turkish separatists, even though it would benefit from defeating Islamic State militants.

headline.main: Turkey Inching Toward Alliance With U.S. in Syria Conflict
headline.print_headline: Turkey Inching Toward Alliance in Syria Conflict

snippet: The popular election of Recep Tayyip Erdogan as its next president creates political uncertainties for his country.
lead_paragraph: The popular election of Recep Tayyip Erdogan as its next president creates political uncertainties for his country.
abstract: Editorial holds Recep Tayip Erdogan's victory in Turkey's first direct presidential election poses significant dangers for the country and allies like the United States that have long depended on it as a stabilizing force in the Middle East; contends Erdogan will now face far fewer obstacles as he pursues the interests of his Islamic-rooted party through ever-stronger executive powers.

headline.seo: Will Recep Tayyip Erdogan Expand His Presidential Powers?
